title: Carrots Don't Give You Night Vision
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Carrots Don't Give You Night Vision.

hook.text: Parents worldwide tell children: 'Eat your carrots â€” they'll help you see in the dark.' It's war propaganda.

buildup.text: Carrots contain beta-carotene, which the body converts to vitamin A â€” essential for eye function.

discovery.text: Vitamin A deficiency can cause night blindness. But extra vitamin A beyond normal levels doesn't enhance vision.

twist.text: Britain spread the carrot myth in WWII to hide their radar technology from Germany.

climax.text: They claimed RAF pilots ate carrots for night vision â€” distracting from the real secret: airborne radar.

punchline.text: Carrots are healthy. But the night-vision story was a military cover-up.

quiz.question: Why did Britain promote the idea that carrots improve night vision during WWII?
options: To conceal their use of radar technology
